awd_titl_txt: Criticality and Nonlinearity in Interacting Particle Systems and Stochastic Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
The project concerns the time evolution of large, stochastic systems, with a focus on their nonlinear and critical behaviors. The systems studied in this project are representative of natural phenomena, such as crystal growths, evolution of magnetic domains, paths evolving in a noisy environment, and randomly stirred fluids. Often these systems exhibit nonlinearity and criticality. Nonlinearity refers to the behavior that the randomness of the macroscopic observables are related to the underlying microscopic randomness in a nonlinear fashion. Criticality refers to the phenomenon that a given system exhibits drastically distinct macroscopic behaviors when certain parameters in the underlying microscopic model reach some critical values. Time-evolutionary stochastic systems form a large body of probability theory, yet the type of phenomena considered here sits on the frontiers of current standard theories. The goal of this project is to unveil the mathematical structure pertaining to the aforementioned scopes, and to refine the existing theories to study these systems.

In concrete terms, the project studies three types of models: interacting particles with moving boundaries, stochastic partial differential equaitons (SPDEs) at their criticality, and stochastic six vertex-types models. Particle systems with moving boundaries give rise to Stefan?s problem in PDE, and in one particular case those systems relate to the critical point of a reaction-diffusion particle system. The principal investigator seeks to develop more robust tools that do not require explicit stationary distributions and apply to the aforementioned critical point. SPDEs exhibit criticality for certain parameters, where the solutions become non-measurable with respect to the driving noise. This research aims at studying the correlation functions, regularity, and local properties of a few specific examples of such SPDEs. The stochastic six-vertex model is a specialization of the ice-type models that can be formulated as a Markov process. It hosts a number of degenerations, including the totally asymmetric simple exclusion process. As a first step toward understanding the limiting shape of these models, the principal investigator plans to study the large deviations utilizing the Markov structures of these models.

por.por_cntn:
Interacting particle systems and stochastic Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) are ubiquitous in science nowadays. They can be used to model a wide range of phenomena: traffic follows, heat transfer, spread of diseases, evolution of magnetic domains, stock prices, queuing, randomly stirred fluids, randomly growing interfaces, just to name a few. Besides being of great application values, these systems and equations post interesting and challenging mathematical questions. Understanding and predicting their behaviors have formed a major strand of modern probability research.

In this project, we focus on the critical and nonlinear behaviors of interacting particle systems and stochastic PDEs. Being critical means the system is at the brink of changing behaviors. Sometimes, as certain parameters (such as the temperature and pressure) vary, the system of interest will change its behaviors, and being critical means being at the point where the change happens. Being nonlinear means the system responds to random forcing nonlinearly: If we double the amount of random forcing in the system, a nonlinear system will not simply double the response. Systems that are critical and/or nonlinear often exhibit intriguing phenomena and analyzing them often requires building new tools.

In this project, we studied various instances of critical and/or nonlinear interacting particle systems and stochastic PDEs, and obtained concrete, new, and interesting results. The type of systems we studied include: diffusions with rank-dependent drift, which arise in mathematical finance and optimization problems, exclusion processes, which arise in the study of discrete lattice gas (and many other subjects), the Kardar--Parisi--Zhang equation, which is an important model in the study of random surface growth, the stochastic heat equation, which describes a string embedded in a random environment, the six vertex model, which is a toy model for the ice formation. We obtained results about their typical large-scale behaviors, their fluctuations around their typical values, and the probabilities of atypical behaviors.

To tackle the aforementioned systems, we have developed new approaches. Our approaches  feature the combined use of stochastic analysis and exact formulas. Stochastic analysis can be viewed as the stochastic cousin of calculus, and is very widely used in science and engineering to tackle stochastic systems. At the same time, the systems that we study often enjoy exact formulas.These formulas arise from a different end of the mathematical spectrum: representation theory and combinatorics. A common approach we take is to start with these formulas and try to extract useful information with the aid of stochastic analysis.

Besides the support to carry out research, the award has supported the PI to attend conferences and workshops, to give seminar talks and conference talks on results obtained in this project, and to invite speakers and researchers to Rutgers University. The award has also enabled the PI to develop novel curricula of courses on stochastic processes and engineering linear algebra.
